pageData.text: Estimate the number of stearic acid molecules in a <button class='glossary-text'>mole</button> of stearic acid based on measurements of the volume of a known mass of stearic acid. This requires that a monolayer film of stearic acid molecules be created on a water surface, allowing the area of a single molecule of stearic acid to be calculated. <button class='glossary-text'>Avogadro’s number</button> will also be estimated by calculating the number of aluminum atoms in a known volume and mass of aluminum foil.

pageData.text: Bottled or purified water should be used because they lack most of the impurities that are found in tap water. Water that has been filtered through a water purifier (e.g., Brita<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> or PUR<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>) works well.

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Practice calculations using volume, mass, <button class='glossary-text'>moles</button>, and molecules to calculate density, concentration, molecular mass, and <button class='glossary-text'>Avogadro’s number</button>.
Determine Avogadro’s number using molecular monolayer techniques.
Calculate the number of stearic acid molecules in a monolayer.
Calculate the moles of stearic acid in a monolayer.

pageData.text: Amedeo Avogadro was born into a world that was making great strides in discovering more about the atom, which had recently been discovered but whose behavior was still a mystery. This incredibly small piece of matter brought about incredibly large numbers when determining how many atoms were in everyday objects, but with the discovery of <button class='glossary-text'>Avogadro’s number</button> this feat became manageable. Although Avogadro did not actually discover this value, he did produce the idea that led scientists to determine it, and therefore the value is named in his honor. This value is also referred to as a <button class='glossary-text'>mole</button>.

The mole unit is like a dozen. If we have a dozen items, it does not matter what the item is, we know we have twelve of those. The mole is similar in that it does not matter what the item is, the mole says there are 6.02 X 1023 of them. So, Avogadro’s number says it does not matter what atom or molecules we are referring to, it states that one mole of substance “A” has the same number of items as substance “B.” You can see how useful the mole is when you imagine having to write 602,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 atoms during any calculations.

pageData.desc: A dozen eggs in a paper carton.
pageData.altText: A dozen eggs in a paper carton.

pageData.subTitle: Avogadro’s Number
pageData.text: Atoms are inherently small and have a mass that cannot be measured by traditional methods. Scientists have defined the mass of a single proton or neutron as 1.00 amu or atomic mass units (electrons weigh much less). The mass of a single carbon-12 atom that contains 6 protons and 6 neutrons is 12.00 amu. To connect the atomic or molecular world to the macroscopic world, the concept of the was developed. One mole of atoms has been defined by scientists as the number of atoms of carbon-12 that have a mass of 12.00 g. There are 6.022 × 1023 atoms of carbon-12 in a mole. This number of particles in a mole is called . It is named after the early 19th century Italian scientist, Amedeo Avogadro, who first proposed that the volume of a gas is proportional to the number of atoms or molecules regardless of the nature of the gas.

pageData.question: Which of the following statements is true?

options.text: There are 6.022 x 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup> atoms of carbon-12 in a mole.
There are 6.022 x 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>23</sup> atoms of carbon-12 in a mole.
There are 6.022 atoms of carbon-12 in a mole.
There are 2.206 x 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>23</sup> atoms of carbon-12 in a mole.
There are 6.022 x 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>3</sup> atoms of carbon-12 in a mole.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: There are 6.022 x 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>23</sup> atoms of carbon-12 in a mole.

pageData.question: What is the variable used to represent Avogadro’s number?

options.text: V<sub class='bodySubscript'>a</sub> with the accepted value of 6.02214 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>23</sup> particles/mole.
N<sub class='bodySubscript'>V</sub> with the accepted value of 6.02214 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>23</sup> particles/mole.
A<sub class='bodySubscript'>N</sub> with the accepted value of 6.02214 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>23</sup> particles/mole.
A<sub class='bodySubscript'>v</sub> with the accepted value of 6.02214 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>23</sup> particles/mole.
N<sub class='bodySubscript'>a</sub> with the accepted value of 6.02214 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>23</sup> particles/mole.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Avogadro’s number is represented by N<sub class='bodySubscript'>a</sub> and has the accepted value of 6.02214 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>23</sup> particles/mole.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Avogadro’s number and the concept of the mole are so important to scientists that the mole is one of the seven base units in the International System of Units (SI). Avogadro’s number is represented by N<sub class='bodySubscript'>a</sub> and has the accepted value of 6.02214 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>23</sup> particles/mole. A mole of any substance contains Avogadro’s number of particles. For example, there are 6.022 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>23</sup> atoms of carbon-12 in a mole. One mole of atoms has also been defined by scientists as the number of atoms of carbon-12 that have a mass of 12.00 g.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Avogadro’s number and the concept of the mole are so important to scientists that the mole is one of the seven base units in the International System of Units (SI). Avogadro’s number is represented by N<sub class='bodySubscript'>a</sub> and has the accepted value of 6.02214 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>23</sup> particles/mole. A mole of any substance contains Avogadro’s number of particles. For example, there are 6.022 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>23</sup> atoms of carbon-12 in a mole. One mole of atoms has also been defined by scientists as the number of atoms of carbon-12 that have a mass of 12.00 g.

pageData.text: and the concept of the are so important to scientists that the mole is one of the seven base units in the International System of Units (SI). Avogadro’s number is represented by Na and has the accepted value of 6.02214 × 1023 particles/mole. A mole of any substance contains Avogadro’s number of particles. The value of Avogadro’s number has been determined experimentally since the early 1900s.

In this investigation, Avogadro’s number will be first determined by calculating the amount of stearic acid in a monolayer based on the area and the number of moles of stearic acid. It will also be determined by calculating the number of aluminum atoms in a known volume and mass of aluminum. Both of these determinations rely on several assumptions and an estimation of the size of these molecules. Therefore, this investigation will provide an estimation of Avogadro’s number that should be within an order of magnitude of the actual number.

pageData.subTitle: Stearic Acid
pageData.text: Stearic acid is a fatty acid that has the condensed structural formula CH3(CH2)16CO2H (see Figure 1).

pageData.desc: Figure 1: structural model of stearic acid molecule
pageData.altText: Figure 1: structural model of stearic acid molecule

pageData.text: Fatty acids are a natural product; they can be extracted from many plant sources, such as corn, soybeans, and peanuts, and have many commercial applications. The structure of the molecule is responsible for its unique properties, one of which is its solubility in water. The acid end of the molecule is polar and soluble in water but the hydrocarbon portion of the molecule is nonpolar and is hydrophobic, or not water-soluble. Therefore, if a small amount of stearic acid is added to water, the polar ends of the molecule will be soluble in the water and nonpolar portion of the molecule will stick out of the water as shown in Figure 2.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: arrangement of stearic acid molecules in a monolayer
pageData.altText: Figure 2: arrangement of stearic acid molecules in a monolayer

pageData.text: When stearic acid is carefully layered on top of water as shown in Figure 2, it is called a monolayer. In a monolayer of a fatty acid such as stearic acid, the molecules are arranged vertically as close as possible in a single layer. If the area of the monolayer and the mass of stearic acid are both measured and the area of a single molecule of stearic acid is known, then the number of molecules in the monolayer can be calculated.

In this investigation, a solution of stearic acid in hexane is used. Hexane, C<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>14</sub>, is a nonpolar hydrocarbon that is insoluble in water and also very volatile (it readily evaporates). Carefully adding drops of the stearic acid solution to water will create a monolayer of stearic acid molecules once the hexane evaporates.

pageData.subTitle: Sample Calculations
pageData.text: The calculations necessary to estimate the number of molecules in a using this procedure are demonstrated in this sample calculation. The following sample experimental data will be used in the calculations.

• The concentration of stearic acid in hexane is 0.10 g/L
  • 0.53 mL of stearic acid solution is used
  • A 100-cm-long thread loop is used

pageData.subTitle: Mass and Moles of Stearic Acid
pageData.text: Step 1: Determine the mass of stearic acid that is added to the water by multiplying the volume and concentration. mass volume = concentrationmass = volume × concentrationmass = 0.53 mL × 1 L1,000 mL × 0.1 g1 Lmass = 0.000053 g
Step 2: Determine the number of of stearic acid using the molecular weight of stearic acid (284.5 g/mol).moles = grams molecular weight moles = 5.3 × 10-5 g 284.5 g/mol moles = 1.86 × 10-7 mol

pageData.subTitle: Area of the Stearic Acid Monolayer
pageData.text: The stearic acid will be contained inside a loop of thread so the area can be easily calculated. When the loop is completely filled with a monolayer of stearic acid, it will form a circle, which is the most efficient shape in that it has the greatest area-to-perimeter ratio. If the circumference of the circle is known, then the area inside the circle is also known. If the length of thread used in the experiment is 100 cm long, then the circumference of the circle is 100 cm.
Step 1: Determine the radius of the circle.Circumference of circle = 2 πr (where π is 3.14 and r is the radius)100.0 cm = 2 × 3.14 × r15.9 cm = r
Step 2: Determine the area of the loop.Area = πr2Area = π × (15.9 cm)2Area = 794 cm2

pageData.question:
Noah is performing this investigation in another class. Help him calculate the mass of stearic acid that is added to the water under the following conditions:
  • The concentration of stearic acid in hexane is 0.410 g/L.
  • 8.71 mL of stearic acid solution is used.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: concentration = mass / volume (in liters)mass = volume x concentration (in liters)8.71 mL x 1 L / 1000 mL = 0.00871 Lmass = 0.00871 L x 0.410 g/L = 0.0035711 g = 0.00357 g stearic acid

pageData.question: How many moles of stearic acid are used in 3.57 * 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>-3</sup> g of stearic acid? The molecular weight of stearic acid is 284.5 g/mol.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: moles = grams / molecular weightmoles = 3.57 × 10-3 grams / 284.5 g/molmoles = 0.000012548330404 mol stearic acid = 1.25 × 10-5 mol stearic acid

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
As part of this investigation, you will need to calculate the mass and moles of stearic acid. Determine the mass of stearic acid that is added to the water by multiplying the volume and concentration. mass volume = concentrationmass = volume × concentrationmass = 0.53 mL × 1 L1,000 mL × 0.1 g1 Lmass = 0.000053 g
Then, Determine the number of moles of stearic acid using the molecular weight of stearic acid (284.5 g/mol). moles = grams molecular weight moles = 5.3 × 10-5 g 284.5 g/mol moles = 1.86 × 10-7 mol

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
As part of this investigation, you will need to calculate the mass and moles of stearic acid. Determine the mass of stearic acid that is added to the water by multiplying the volume and concentration. mass volume = concentrationmass = volume × concentrationmass = 0.53 mL × 1 L1,000 mL × 0.1 g1 Lmass = 0.000053 g
Then, Determine the number of moles of stearic acid using the molecular weight of stearic acid (284.5 g/mol). moles = grams molecular weight moles = 5.3 × 10-5 g 284.5 g/mol moles = 1.86 × 10-7 mol

pageData.subTitle: Area of One Stearic Acid Molecule
pageData.text: Scientists have determined from x-ray diffraction and advanced calculations from space-filling models that the length of a stearic acid molecule in a monolayer is 24.7 Å and the area is 20.7 Å2. One angstrom (Å) is 10–10 meters or 10–8 cm. Therefore, one stearic acid molecule occupies 20.7 × 10–16 cm2.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: cylindrical dimensions of a stearic acid molecule
pageData.altText: Figure 3: cylindrical dimensions of a stearic acid molecule

pageData.subTitle: Calculation of Number of Stearic Acid Molecules
pageData.text: If a monolayer is formed, then the number of stearic acid molecules multiplied by the area of one stearic acid molecule should equal the area of the circular loop.
Total Area = (# of Stearic Acid Molecules) × (area of one Stearic Acid Molecule)
749 cm<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup> = (# of Stearic Acid Molecules) × (20.7 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>–16</sup> cm<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup>)
(# of Stearic Acid Molecules) = 3.62 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>17</sup> molecules

pageData.subTitle: Calculation of Avogadro’s Number
pageData.text: The number of stearic acid molecules in a known quantity of of stearic acid is now known. can be determined using a simple ratio.
Avogadro’s number 1 Mole × 3.62 × 1017 molecules 1.86 × 10-7 moles
Avogadro’s number = 1.95 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>24</sup> molecules

pageData.subTitle: Aluminum Metal
pageData.text: The second activity will test your math skills and ability to estimate . Use a sample of aluminum foil and develop a step-by-step procedure and calculations to determine Avogadro’s number and to estimate the layers of aluminum atoms in the sheet of aluminum foil. The following data are required to solve these problems.
Density of aluminum: 2.70 g/cm<sup class='bodySupscript'>3</sup>
Volume of a sphere = (4/3) πr<sup class='bodySupscript'>3</sup>
Atomic mass of aluminum: 26.98 g/mol
Atomic radius of aluminum: 143 pm (picometer = 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>–12</sup> meters)

pageData.question: A monolayer of stearic acid is formed while using a 100-cm-long thread to create a loop which will contain the stearic acid. Assume the total area of the loop is 788 cm<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup> and one stearic acid molecule occupies 20.7 x 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>–16</sup> cm<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup> . Calculate how many stearic acid molecules are contained within the loop.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Total Area = (# of stearic acid molecules) x (area of one stearic acid molecule)# of stearic acid molecules = Total Area / area of one stearic acid molecule# of stearic acid molecules = 788 cm2 / 20.7 x 10–16 cm2# of stearic acid molecules = 3.806763285024 x 1017 = 3.81 x 1017 molecules stearic acid

pageData.question:
Use the following information and ratio to calculate Avogadro’s number.
  • Number of stearic acid molecules = 3.81 x 1017 molecules
  • Moles of stearic acid used = 1.25 x 10-5 mol
  • Avogadro’s number 1 mol × number of stearic acid molecules moles of stearic acid used

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Avogadro’s number 1 mol × number of stearic acid molecules moles of stearic acid used Avogadro’s number 1 mol × 3.81 x 1017 1.25 x 10-5 Avogadro’s number = 3.048 x 1022 = 3.05 x 1022

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: If a monolayer is formed, then the number of stearic acid molecules multiplied by the area of one stearic acid molecule should equal the area of the circular loop. The formula for calculating the total area of the monolayer is:(# of stearic acid molecules) x (area of one stearic acid molecule).You can use this formula to solve the number of stearic acid molecules by rearranging the formula to read:# of stearic acid molecules = Total Area / area of one stearic acid moleculeOnce you have the number of stearic acid molecules in a known quantity of moles of stearic acid, you can determine Avogadro’s number using this ratio: Avogadro’s number 1 Mole x 3.62 x 1017 molecules 1.86 x 10-7 moles

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: If a monolayer is formed, then the number of stearic acid molecules multiplied by the area of one stearic acid molecule should equal the area of the circular loop. The formula for calculating the total area of the monolayer is:(# of stearic acid molecules) x (area of one stearic acid molecule).You can use this formula to solve the number of stearic acid molecules by rearranging the formula to read:# of stearic acid molecules = Total Area / area of one stearic acid moleculeOnce you have the number of stearic acid molecules in a known quantity of moles of stearic acid, you can determine Avogadro’s number using this ratio: Avogadro’s number 1 Mole × 3.62 x 1017 molecules 1.86 x 10-7 moles

pageData.desc: This map describes the workflow for this investigation. To start Activity 1, fill a plate with water, then create a loop of thread and determine the loop’s length. Then, place the loop on the water’s surface. Next, add stearic acid dropwise to the loop area until a stearic acid monolayer is formed. Then, determine the volume of stearic acid used and measure the monolayer’s diameter. This activity is repeated for a total of two trials. Then, calculate the number of stearic acid molecules in the monolayer and calculate Avogadro’s number. In Activity 2, you will obtain a sheet of aluminum foil and measure the dimensions and mass of the foil. Then, calculate Avogadro’s number and the number of layers of aluminum atoms in the foil.
pageData.altText: This map describes the workflow for this investigation. To start Activity 1, fill a plate with water, then create a loop of thread and determine the loop’s length. Then, place the loop on the water’s surface. Next, add stearic acid dropwise to the loop area until a stearic acid monolayer is formed. Then, determine the volume of stearic acid used and measure the monolayer’s diameter. This activity is repeated for a total of two trials. Then, calculate the number of stearic acid molecules in the monolayer and calculate Avogadro’s number. In Activity 2, you will obtain a sheet of aluminum foil and measure the dimensions and mass of the foil. Then, calculate Avogadro’s number and the number of layers of aluminum atoms in the foil.

pageData.text: Read all of the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely. Observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).
The stearic acid in hexane solution is a flammable liquid. Keep away from all flames and heat sources. Use the hexane solution in a well-ventilated area.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum during this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after the activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

Read the activities.
Obtain all materials.

In Activity 1, you will create a monolayer of stearic acid on the surface of water by containing the monolayer in a thread loop. You will measure the dimensions of the thread loop and the volume of stearic acid dispensed to calculate the number of stearic acid molecules in the monolayer as well as <button class='glossary-text'>Avogadro’s number</button>.

pages.title: Activity 1
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Determination of Avogadro’s Number Using Stearic Acid Monolayer (25 steps)

pageData.text: Lay a towel on the counter to catch excess water during the experiment.
Fill the glass plate or dish with purified water until the water level is slightly overfilled.

The water level should be as high as possible. Water will form a slight curved surface above the container due to surface tension. This slight dome will help keeping the monolayer within the thread loop.
Cut a piece of thread approximately 25 cm long.
Create a loop by tying the two ends together using a double knot.
Cut any excess thread from the knots. Trim the ends as close to the knot as possible.
Pull the loop tight and measure this length. Then, multiply this length by two to determine the length of the loop of thread. Record the length of the loop in Data Table 1.
Carefully place the thread loop on the surface of the water. View the following video on how to create the stearic acid monolayer loop:

The thread loop should easily float on the surface of the water. Try to spread the loop out using a toothpick or pin. The thread should not overlap itself. Avoid pushing the thread under the water or completely wetting it.
Inspect the thread to ensure that all parts of the thread are in contact with the water.

If the thread is not touching the surface, it may kink. Manipulate the thread loop to make sure the thread is touching the water in all places. The thread loop is essentially a floating dam to retain the monolayer. It is essential that there are no gaps between the thread and the surface through which the monolayer can escape.
Fill the syringe with the stearic acid solution. Fill the syringe almost full with solution and then remove any air bubbles by squirting out a small amount of solution.
Practice using the syringe to release only one drop of solution at a time.
Record the starting volume of solution in Data Table 1.
Slowly add a few drops of solution into the center of the loop area. Add drops one at a time.
After a few drops, the thread loop should form a firm circle. At this time, stop adding stearic acid solution.
The hexane will begin to evaporate and the thread loop should begin to contract, forming a noncircular shape.
Continue to add a drop or two of stearic acid solution until a perfect circle is formed and remains a circle even after the hexane has evaporated.

A sustained, firm circle of thread indicates that a monolayer of stearic acid has been formed inside this circle. If an added drop of stearic acid solution strikes the surface, remains on top of the monolayer, and requires a prolonged period of time to disappear, then the monolayer is complete.
Record the ending volume of solution in Data Table 1.
Verify the diameter of the circle by holding a ruler just above the surface of the water.
Dispose of the water, stearic acid, and thread in your plate or dish.
Repeat this procedure for an additional trial.
Calculate the mass of stearic acid for each trial and record in Data Table 1.
Mass = concentration × volume
Calculate the of stearic acid for each trial and record in Data Table 1.
Moles = mass/mol weight
Mol Weight = 284.5 g/mol
Record the area of stearic acid for each trial in Data Table 1.
Area of Stearic Acid = Area of Loop
Calculate the number of stearic acid molecules for each and record in Data Table 1.
Number of Stearic acid molecules = Area of Stearic Acid/Area of One Stearic Acid Molecule
Calculate for each trial and record in Data Table 1.
Avogadro’s Number = Number of Stearic Acid Molecules/Moles of Stearic Acid

This activity is intended as an extension activity and requires the application of concepts from the Background and Activity 1 to solve a mathematical problem. You will measure the dimensions and mass of a sheet of aluminum foil to calculate <button class='glossary-text'>Avogadro’s number</button> as well as the number of layers of aluminum atoms in the foil sheet.

pages.title: Activity 2
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Determination of Avogadro’s Number Using Aluminum Foil (7 steps)

typeBefore.text: The following activity is intended as an extension activity and requires the application of concepts from the Background and Activity 1 to solve a mathematical problem.

pageData.text: Cut a piece of aluminum foil about 12 inches in length.
Trim the aluminum foil using the straight edge of a ruler to ensure that both edges are straight. The straighter the edges, the easier it is to accurately measure the length of the foil.
Carefully measure the length and width of the aluminum foil in centimeters. Record the values in Data Table 2.
Fold the aluminum foil so that it fits on the balance.
Weigh the aluminum foil and record the mass in Data Table 2.
Calculate <button class='glossary-text'>Avogadro’s number</button> using a procedure similar to that used during the stearic acid monolayer activity. Use the data below to perform your calculations.
Density of aluminum: 2.70 g/cm3
Volume of a sphere = (4/3) πr3
Atomic mass of aluminum: 26.98 g/mol
Atomic radius of aluminum: 143 pm (picometer = 10–12 meters)
Calculate the number of layers of aluminum atoms in the aluminum foil sheet assuming each aluminum atom is stacked on top of one another and are touching.

text: Open up the bottle containing the stearic acid/hexane solution and allow the hexane to evaporate. Next, seal the bottle and dispose of it in the trash.
Clean and dry all of the equipment, and return all items to the equipment kit.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

tableData.text:
Length of Thread Used
Note: Measure after the loop is made. This will be the circumference of the circle.

Area of Loop
Area = π r2
Initial Volume of Stearic Acid Solution in Syringe [mL]
Final Volume of Stearic Acid Solution in Syringe [mL]
Concentration of Stearic Acid in Hexane

Mass of Stearic Acid
Mass = concentration × volume

Moles of Stearic Acid
Moles = mass / mol weight
Mol Weight = 284.5 g / mol

Area of Stearic Acid
Area of Stearic Acid = Area of Loop

Number of Stearic Acid Molecules
Area of Stearic Acid / Area of One Stearic Acid Molecule

Avogadro’s Number
Number of Stearic Acid Molecules / Moles of Stearic Acid

pageData.title: Questions
text: Describe the appearance of the monolayer and the thread, as the first drops of stearic acid were added to the water.
Describe the appearance of the monolayer and thread as the last drops of stearic acid were added to the water.
If some the hexane had evaporated from the stearic acid solution, what effect (if any) would it have on the experimental value of Avogadro’s number? Why?
What assumptions are made in the stearic acid experiment to calculate the value of Avogadro’s number?
What is the percent error for your experimental determination of Avogadro’s number?
What are three possible sources of error in the stearic acid experiment?

Avogadro’s Number
Number of Aluminum Atoms / Moles of Aluminum

pageData.text: Write out a step-by-step procedure for how to perform each of the steps below to determine Avogadro's number using aluminum foil.
Density of aluminum: 2.70 g/cm3
Volume of a sphere = (4/3) πr3
Atomic mass of aluminum: 26.98 g/mol
Atomic radius of aluminum: 143 pm (picometer = 10–12 meters)

text: Determine the volume of the aluminum foils using the density of foil.
Determine the volume of one atom of aluminum.
Determine the number of atoms of aluminum in the foil sample.
Determine the moles of aluminum.
Calculate Avogadro’s number.
Determine the thickness of the aluminum foil.
If aluminum atoms are stacked on top of each other and one aluminum atom has a diameter of 286 pm or 2.86 × 10<sup class='bodySupscript'>-8</sup> cm, and calculate how many layers are in the foil.
Based on your data, what value for Avogadro’s number was calculated?
What is the percent error for your experimental determination of Avogadro’s number?
Determine the number of layers of atoms, assuming each aluminum atom is stacked on top of one another and are touching from the data above.
What are some possible sources of error in the aluminum foil experiment?

pageData.altText: Figure 1: structural model of stearic acid molecule

pageData.content: Figure 2. Arrangement of stearic acid molecules in water
pageData.altText: Figure 2: arrangement of stearic acid molecules in a monolayer

pageData.content: Figure 3. Length and area of a stearic acid molecule
pageData.altText: Figure 3: cylindrical dimensions of a stearic acid molecule

This map describes the workflow for this investigation. To start Activity 1, fill a plate with water, then create a loop of thread and determine the loop’s length. Then, place the loop on the water’s surface. Next, add stearic acid dropwise to the loop area until a stearic acid monolayer is formed. Then, determine the volume of stearic acid used and measure the monolayer’s diameter. This activity is repeated for a total of two trials. Then, calculate the number of stearic acid molecules in the monolayer and calculate Avogadro’s number. In Activity 2, you will obtain a sheet of aluminum foil and measure the dimensions and mass of the foil. Then, calculate Avogadro’s number and the number of layers of aluminum atoms in the foil.

data.title: Avogadro’s number
data.content: There are 6.022 × 1023 atoms of carbon-12 in a mole, this number of particles in a mole is Avogadro’s number.

data.title: Mole
data.content: One mole of atoms has been defined by scientists as the number of atoms of carbon-12 that have a mass of 12.00 g; there are 6.022 × 1023 atoms of carbon-12 in a mole.
